title: So has Veigar now officially been slapped by the ChampUp Trademark "Fixed" sticker then?
body:
Has riot sufficiently pumped enough excessive power into his most boring and only usable skill that he has a high enough winrate they can point to and say "there now he's fine" and he's ready to join the ranks of Skarner Rengar Olaf Casseopia Viktor Karma and the other "Successful" reworks? Doomed to forever exist but be so hideously countered by League of Mobility that he will never be picked, locked in a limbo of stagnation?

It kinda looks like it. So his W and E will never get to become interesting, usable skills? Well, rats. 

Seriously, Champion Update team, why do you do this? Why are you convinced that the most fun skills in the entire game are either A) line skillshots or B) Targeted damage taps? How long are we going to get stuck with the following formula:

1) Did this champion have a targeted skill? If yes,

2) Make it a skillshot! Maybe with a slow! Did this champion have skillshots that didnt end up working out too well?

3) Load power into a targeted skill, that'll make the champion more reliable! 

Finally 4) Add a stupid gimmick/mini-game that nobody likes playing.

Final check 5) Make sure champion still has no way to deal with mobility creep. If they do, nerf it immediately following their release.

replies.body: Hey, Viktor actually *was* successful (they fixed his passive and that's about it). Karma is healthy and balanced (although not necessarily pleasing to Karma players because she is not the same champ she used to be). Skarner isn't that bad right now, he just has a different type of stickiness and his durability comes mostly from his shield to make up for the removal of the heal proc from E. Rengar, Cass, Olaf, and Veigar though? Yeah, Riot screwed them up pretty handily (rengar not *as* badly, but still on a similar spectrum).

Viktor only vanished due to a bug that left him disabled for all of 5.5. 
Cass is fairly common.
Olaf and Rengar see play in LCK and LPL.
Karma overlaps way too much with Lulu.

Honestly, we're on a patch where first picking Urgot and playing Nautilus support are considered normal. And forgotten champions like Twitch, Udyr, Zac and Shyvana seeing play.

When I say Riot screwed up the last 4, I don't mean that they are weak, I mean that they are unhealthy. Rengar is even more feast or famine than he used to be. Olaf is still a totally one dimensional feast or famine fighter who either becomes totally immortal as the game goes on, or becomes relatively useless. Cass is broken as heck. Her balance may be fine at the moment, but her passive is trash and her kit is very toxic and anti-fun to play against. Veigar had all of his power loaded into Q, and now basically has one real spell until 6 unless the *enemy* screws up, which means you are quite helpless to actually express your skill with Veigar anymore.

You keep using buzzwords but I'm not too sure if you know what they mean.

* Rengar is a snowbally early game champion with very little lategame carry potential outside of certain pick comps (which aren't seeing play atm) and being a ball delivery system for Orianna.
* Olaf doesn't have the greatest early game and needs some help getting going. And even when fed, he still effectively needs Lulu on his team to be relevant. That's not feast or famine, that's being extremely niche and team dependent.
* In the grand scheme of things, the differences between S2 and S5 Cass' play patterns are fairly minimal. Are you really calling a low defensive mobility, short range, skill shot oriented kit with no non-ultimate hard CC toxic?
* Most of Veigar's budget was in his E, which got nerfed so it could be moved elsewhere.

I still consider the Rengar rework a failure because NOTHING changed.  The only noticeable changes was his E being a skillshot and Bonetooth Necklace no longer being an item.  Otherwise he still one shots from stealth, his teamfight still sucks, and he still relies on snowballing to be relevant.  They fixed nothing about him that was problematic (aside from gutting his ability to splitpush, though it WAS broken).

I know very well what I meant when I was speaking before. 

* Rengar is snowbally (also referred to as feast or famine), and you summed up exactly what I meant about him.
* For Olaf, My point is that outside rare cases where his team works with him, he is feast or famine. If he doesn't have a Lulu and/or doesn't have a team that works with him (pretty common in solo queue) he usually is either very strong or very weak throughout the game (kind of what feast or famine means isn't it?).
* Cass's rework is toxic because her passive is broken. Since when does being broken require that a champion needs CC or mobility? Her kit was toxic before the rework (that's why they reworked her) but they didn't end up fixing anything and only succeeded in pushing all of her strength into one ability and really p###ing off her player base. Her problem isn't that she is suddenly toxic out of the blue, it is that they didn't fix anything and the bad parts stick out even more (she's still a lane bully, and she is *still* a late game hyper carry).
* Veigar was actually much healthier to play against before the recent changes. Sure I couldn't dodge the stun as well (but I could just get merc treads or Abyssal Scepter or any other MR+Health item), but I had the ability to bully him out of lane and he actually had to land his full combo to kill me before the game got rolling. Now there is very little I can do to keep him from farming, but he also doesn't scale as well, leaving him with an ok early game and very strong mid game before tapering off in the late game again, which *should not happen*. They still didn't address the way his kit is all about "If I land stun, odds are you're dead, If I don't land stun, odds are I'm dead." *NOTHING* about his kit has changed except that he has a higher chance to fail. That does not make his kit healthy, that just makes it so that there are fewer instances of him actually pulling off the full combo. As the Veigar, it feels terrible since you miss so many more times than before, and as the opponent, getting hit by that one unlucky stun feels just as terrible as before. They rebudgeted his power all right, but that is the worst thing they did, because they didn't actually take the real power (a super long stun) they took the perceived power (how fast it comes out), which leaves him more binary to play against than ever.

None of my points were about how they do in the pro scene, they were about how healthy they are in terms of the quality of time playing as them and the quality of time playing against them.

* Feast or famine refers to champions that takeover the game when fed but are a liability when behind (i.e.: Old Kassadin). Olaf is merely team reliant.
* Toxicity refers mainly to play patterns that aren't fun to play against. Lack of counterplay and heavy snowballing (i.e.: S2 Darius) being the two most common ones. You can call Cass' passive a boring gating mechanic, but toxic is not the word for it.
* A champion is healthy when they're not toxic. It has nothing to do with the actual player experience and everything to do with their opponent's.

How does Olaf not fit that definition? Like I said, if he doesn't have a good team (as in, both good teammates and good allied champions), he can easily become quite useless. When he has a good team or by some luck gets a really strong lead, he takes over a game single handedly.

Cass's passive is a gating mechanic primarily, but it is naturally a *snowbally low counterplay stat gaining mechanic*. Her kit is naturally toxic (using your definition) because she is a lane bully, falls off mid game, and then comes back with a vengeance late game. If she has a strong early game, then her mid game is gone before it is even noticeable, but if she has a weak early game, her mid game is that much worse and her late game often takes to long in coming to compensate. How is that not excessively snowbally?

I clearly said that I was basing my opinions off of *2* things; Playing *as* the champions and playing *against* the champions. I never said that the parts I was claiming were toxic were from my analysis *as* them, and I thought I made it pretty clear I was talking about playing against them when I brought those points up (sorry if it wasn't, I didn't mean for any confusion).

While most "feast or famine" champions are snowbally, there's very few champions in this game that cannot capitalize on having a gold/experience lead. In Olaf's case, it's not even tied to him requiring farm or the need to snowball. His usefulness is completely based on his team and what he's facing.

You can be a lane bully while having a healthy play pattern. In Cass' case, we're talking about skillshots that can be missed or dodged and a low range conditional point and click. Her passive is completely irrelevant in this discussion, you don't die because her passive gives her a bunch of stats mid-late game, you die to Cass because you walked into poison and she twin fanged you to death. Counterplay? Don't get hit by skillshots.

Don't rewrite the meaning for words that have been clearly defined, it kind of defeats the purpose of having those words in the first place. In fact, they've been overused so much that you might as well stop using them completely.

The problem with {{champion:69}}'s bullying, is that it's so relentless. If you come within range of her E, you will be hit repeatedly. I haven't played her, but I've played against her, and only now read up on her abilities.

My conclusion: If you get within range of her E, she poisons you and spams E at a sub 1 second CD. She's got two poison abilities, both of which are point and click AoE, not the hardest to hit with.

If I can get within E range you lose half your health if you stay there for more than 2 seconds.

If you get out ASAP maybe you only lose 1/4 or 1/5 of it instead.

And if she fails her combo she waits 5 seconds and can try again.

And to top that off she has a really good mana regen mechanic on her E while farming and naturally kinda high base mana regen.

And she scales into late game.

She has ridiculously low cooldowns on most of her kit, and gets free CDR.

The problem isn't that she's a lane bully.

The problem is that she's a hyper bully and a late game powerhouse.

Who doesn't have any meaningful downtime. As long as I don't go OOM I'm fine.

Well... being a lane bully is fine.. but you really shouldn't have a champion which is a lane bully and a late game carry.... after all being weaker early game is usually the price late game champions pay for their late game strength

And nothing really changed though... Cass was reworked because she was an unhealthy lane bully... well she is still a lane bully and now a lane bully with immense damage late game (before she was more of an early to mid game champion)

Rengar, Cass, Olaf, and Veigar though? Yeah, Riot screwed them up pretty handily (rengar not *as* badly, but still on a similar spectrum).

Viktor got power shoved into his point and click nuke and taken out of his two unique moves, and then the move that didn't work still doesn't work. 

But they fixed his Passive, changing it from something with a false choice that had a single best way of using it to something with a false choice and a single best way of using it that was stronger.

Gravity field is actually quite good now (the implosion effect makes landing E so smooth). They did change his style a bit to favor his new Q, but not to the point that he isn't still all about landing E and R. Shifting power away from E was a good and necessary change, because before, that was *all* he had, now he has a full set of very useful abilities that work very well together.

And they really didn't nerf his E at all.  It doesn't have the anti-tank burn, but when it comes to destroying squishy back line targets, i.e. his main job, it is incredibly effective.  A single laser will take a squishy well below half health if he is decently farmed.  By drastically increasing the potential damage on his Q while at the same time making his damage spells 2-part spells, they made him a little worse at killing assassins who are supposed to be his main counters, and significantly better at killing immobile/immobilized squishies which is his job as an APC.  IMO Viktor is one of the best balanced champs in the game atm.  He is extremely good at doing his job, i.e. laying out the damage, while at the same time being extremely easy to lock down and kill with any decent CC like any APC with such a shit load of damage should be.

They raised the CD of his Q by a second, and said it can now hit two things. You can possibly get 2 AP for every Q instead of 1. Great right?

Wrong.

With the 20% AP Ratio reduction on his R, the longer Cooldown on his Q, and the fact that hitting his W is impossible (a loss of another 100% AP ratio), you lost at least 120% AP Ratio grand-total in your kit.

How much AP do you need to farm in order to regain the damage you lost just in ratios? Now, add another large chunk because they removed DFG.

I'll be honest, I'm not sitting down and doing the math right now, but last I checked the "extra" 1 AP you got for every Q didn't come **anywhere** near close to the massive damage loss in Ratios. Even ignoring his ult's ratio loss, you still lost 100% AP Ratio in your kit.
They just made you _think_ that it was amazing. It's still a damage loss until super-late-game, at which point the 300G you would have gotten from normally being able to kill the enemy midlaner when your ult was up more than makes up for the extra handful of AP you got from passively farming your Q.

It isn't a "slightly worse" champ if he doesn't get the W change. He's actually trash until they fix it **and** his E. And depending on how they fix it, he **_still might be worse because they nerfed his ult and his Q is still a damn skillshot._**

> he's ready to join the ranks of Skarner Rengar Olaf Casseopia Viktor Karma and the other "Successful" reworks? Doomed to forever exist but be so hideously countered by League of Mobility that he will never be picked, locked in a limbo of stagnation?

~~With the possible exception of Skarner,~~ they've all seen competitive play this season.

New Veigar might well become more powerful than old Veigar, but he's so much less interesting to play. And if there's one trait common to Veigar mains, it's that they weren't really that interested in playing the most OP champs. (There would be times I would try a FotM mid and just be astonished at how much better I did with them despite literally thousands of Veigar games. But I kept playing Veigar.)

It's funny, too, because by all rights I should be EXACTLY the person to love the Veigar changes:

* I was always really bad at landing my stun with the edge. I got killed a lot as a result. My friends would routinely chide me over it: "Cupcake, you've played like 2,000 Veigar games, why can you not hit with your stupid E?"
* I like trying quirky item builds, and I disliked having to build DFG every match.
* My micro/twitch reflexes are quite poor, and I would often fail to realize that DFG hadn't fired, e.g. because of a range issue or because the spell-queue was overloaded. (Leading to me on the death screen going "Wait, why didn't she die—WHY IS DFG NOT ON COOLDOWN?")
* I love linear long-range skillshots like Ezreal's Q.
* I love delayed abilities like Cho's Rupture, because of all the mindgames you can play.

But I still don't really like New Veigar. Cho's Rupture ("***UP*** you go!") is interesting and effective because it's a filled circle, and it's timed just so that if you place it with the enemy in the center, they have to immediately run for the edge to avoid being knocked up. You can also time it to block a path. It's interesting. Veigar's **[new Event Horizon](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/kMxmMEAE-veigar-tries-to-get-riot-to-make-him-a-new-event-horizon)**, in contrast, really only works if the enemy is an idiot and runs into it, or is already stunned.

Veigar's new power budget seems to be about poke damage and, well, general stat buffs. He feels quite boring in fights.

It's not all bad, no. It's not a disaster. I'll keep trying to learn to like it. As I wrote above, if anyone should like the New Veigar, it should be me. But I'd rather have seen his buff budget poured into giving him a really interesting E that created some strategic choice, rather than just being a stun that only stuns people in Bronze.

All of the reworks that Riot has done were successful at achieving their purposes for the rework, but most players don't see that aspect. They see how the champion is balanced after the rework separate from the goals, and don't take the time to really look at the overarching goals of the rework separated from the balance aspects.

All of these reworks that you mentioned were successful at achieving their purposes, but that doesn't mean that they are in a good spot balance-wise. Veigar's rework was successful strictly from a goal perspective, as his changes were designed to reduce the reliability in his burst and emphasize the Q-farming mechanic. However, players see his rework from the balance perspective, and by that perspective it's easy to see that Veigar's rework was an overwhelming failure.

Cassiopeia, Karma, and Trundle are the only exceptions to this rule. Cassiopeia's rework was a success both in terms of goals (reduce lane bully capacity and accentuate her late-game strengths) and balance (she's seeing quite a bit of competitive play), but a lot of players term it as a failure because they liked to play old Cassiopeia as a poison mage instead of her current style. Karma was a success from goals and balance (at least after a few patches of buffing her), but many players deem it a failure because of how it changed her character. Trundle's "rework" was also successful from both a goals and balance perspective (even though he barely got any kit changes at all), but again, some players are mad that his thematics  got changed.
